moves.1. e4 e5 2. f4: King's gambit that gives a strong and open game for white.
moves.2... exf4 3. Nf3: Needed to prevent Q-h4 and develop the knight at the same time.
moves.3... Nf6 4. Nc3 Bb4 5. e5 Qe7 6. d4 Bxc3: The knight made 3 moves and ended in a bad position, where it gets stuck for the rest of the game.
moves.9... O-O 10. Bd3: Threatening capture of R7 pawn, followed by N-g5 and Q-h5. One can see the faster development on white side which is typical in King's gambit.
moves.10... h6 11. h4: To prevent advancement of g7 pawn.
moves.11... d6: Black opens the line for his bishop threatening to pin the knight at f3.
moves.12. h5: To prevent the black pawn at h6 from advancing further.
moves.12... Bg4 13. Kf2:
Relieving the king from the pin and also moving it closer to other white pieces. 
Opens the option of moving the king to g3, threatening the g4 bishop while protecting 
the otherwise unprotected f4 bishop.
moves.13... Qe6: Another wasted queen move which is a mistake as will be shown next.
moves.14. d5 Qc8:
That is too far and locks the queen in. Q-e7 would have been far better
and would have prevented the coming attack on the king side.
moves.15... Nb8d7:
Too late to bring in the knight. d6Xe5 followed by f7-f6 would have prevented the 
ensuing attack.
moves.16. Bxh6: if g7Xh6, d2Xh6 threatening h6-h7 mate. If f7-f5, e5Xf6 e.p.
moves.16... Re8:
Unfortunate waste of time. This takes the rook away from the scene of action.
f7-f6, e5Xf6, f8Xf6 might have delayed the attack.
moves.17. Qg5: Threatening QXg7 mate. If K-f8, BXg7ch. K-g7,B-f6ch. K-f8 or K-h8,Q-g7 mate.
moves.18. Bxg6:
If PXg6, QXg6. K-h8, Q-g7 mate. If P-f6, B-h7ch. KXh7, Q-g7 mate or K-f6, Q-g7 mate. 
Black resigned at this point. K-h8 would have delayed the game a little but not for long. 
K-h8, B-f8! NXf8,Q-f6ch. K-g8,BXf7ch. K-h7,N-g5 mate. If k-h8, B-f8, RXf8 then Q-h6,
K-g8, Q-h7 mate. If K-h8, B-f8, PXg6 then Q-h6, K-g8, Q-g7 mate.
